title: HOSPITAL Score for Readmissions
description: Predicts potentially avoidable 30-day hospital readmissions in medical patients using seven readily available clinical predictors.

parameters.name: procedure
parameters.description: ICD-9 coded procedure during hospital stay

parameters.name: previous_admissions
parameters.description: Number of hospital admissions in the previous year

parameters.name: length_of_stay
parameters.description: Length of stay for current admission

result.name: hospital_score
result.description: HOSPITAL score indicating risk of potentially avoidable readmission

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of potentially avoidable 30-day readmission (5.8%). Standard discharge planning and follow-up may be sufficient.
Intermediate risk of potentially avoidable 30-day readmission (12.0%). Consider enhanced discharge planning and closer outpatient follow-up.
High risk of potentially avoidable 30-day readmission (22.8%). Intensive transitional care interventions recommended, including early follow-up, medication reconciliation, and care coordination.

references: Donzé J, Aujesky D, Williams D, Schnipper JL. Potentially avoidable 30-day hospital readmissions in medical patients: derivation and validation of a prediction model. JAMA Intern Med. 2013 Apr 22;173(8):632-8.

Donzé JD, Williams MV, Robinson EJ, Zimlichman E, Aujesky D, Vasilevskis EE, et al. International Validity of the HOSPITAL Score to Predict 30-Day Potentially Avoidable Hospital Readmissions. JAMA Intern Med. 2016 Apr;176(4):496-502.
formula: HOSPITAL Score = Hemoglobin points + Oncology points + Sodium points + Procedure points + Index admission type points + Admissions points + Length of stay points
notes: HOSPITAL is an acronym for the included variables
Specifically designed to predict potentially avoidable readmissions, not all readmissions
Does not account for social determinants of health that may impact readmission risk
2-5 previous admissions scores 2 points, >5 scores 5 points
Length of stay ≥5 days scores 2 points
Validated internationally across multiple healthcare systems
